awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Sensing the World: The Development of Tactile Information Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding data is key to scientific literacy in the twenty-first century. This doctoral dissertation project investigates how Science and Technology Studies can contribute to developing new approaches to making technical data intelligible by collaborating with computer scientists. Working with specialists in Human-Computer Interaction, the principal investigators ethnographically investigate how computer scientists seek to translate data visualizations into other sensory modes for visually impaired users. Through historical research, this project documents how the science and technology studies can inform the development of communication technologies for people with disabilities, which will also be the foundation for developing a set of best practices for integrating social analysis into the technical research process.

This project follows a tradition of technically-engaged Science and Technology Studies projects that takes scientific collaboration as a working method and a site of investigation. Using insights from critical disability studies, the history of computing, and sensory studies, the principle investigators explore how discourses of “accessibility” as a design ideal in Human-Computer Interaction always involve implicit ideas about physical, perceptual, and cognitive ability. By using historical and ethnographic methods to make those ideas explicit, this project seeks to improve approaches to conceptualizing and designing communication technologies for people with disabilities. The historical case study of tactile reading systems like braille and haptic computer interfaces serves as an empirical basis for understanding how ideas about ability become embedded in the design of computer interfaces. This project thus draws on the long history of these systems to investigate, inform, and critique the current practice of making multisensory data visualizations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The main goal of the project is to understand the history and practice of making data accessible, with the secondary objective of creating tactics for social scientists and engineers to collaborate on sociotechnical projects. The principal disciplines of this project are science and technology studies, anthropology of science, and human-computer interaction (a sub-discipline in computer science). This project contributes to these disciplines by using insights from disability studies (where there is ample theorization about access) and bringing them to bear alongside technology and disabled people’s lived experience. 

 

As this project unfolded in 2020, the project expanded notions of access by asking how anti-mask groups leverage data throughout the pandemic. This research explored how cultural factors shape the implications of “access” for democratic processes. Using a quantitative analysis of how visualizations spread on Twitter and an ethnographic approach to analyzing conversations about COVID data on Facebook, the co-PI and her collaborators documented an epistemological gap that leads pro- and anti-mask groups to draw drastically different inferences from similar data. Ultimately, the paper argues that the deployment of COVID data visualizations reflect a deeper sociopolitical rift regarding the place of science in public life. This research is important beyond academia because it shows how ill-equipped academics are to talk about how data practices work with non-specialists, and how citizens might use these data to make powerful policy changes. By expanding notions of access and who gets to use data, this project can bring insight into questions about public data (re)use and the future of data-driven decision-making. 

 

The work from this grant also tackles notions of access as they relate to current web accessibility guidelines. Data visualization designers should support basic non-visual alternatives for screen readers, like textual descriptions and access to raw data tables. But charts do more than summarize data or reproduce tables; they afford interactive data exploration at varying levels of granularity. In response to the lack of comparable non-visual data representations, the co-PI and her collaborators designed a set of rich screen reader experiences for accessible data visualization and exploration. Through an iterative co-design process, they identified three design dimensions that are key for expressive screen reader accessibility: structure, or how the entities in a chart should be represented for a screen reader to traverse; navigation, which describes the structural, spatial, and targeted operations a user might perform to step through data; and, description, which identifies the semantic content, composition, and verbosity of the screen reader’s narration. The findings suggest that these designs help users conceptualize data spatially, selectively attend to data of interest at different levels of granularity, and experience control and agency over their data analysis process. In other words, rich and accessible data representations are within designers’ reach, and expands the role of interactivity in data visualization research to include non-visual interfaces.

 

The research from this project formed the basis of the co-PI’s dissertation, which she successfully defended in summer 2022. This work has resulted in ten invited colloquium talks, three conference proceedings, two peer-reviewed journal articles, two workshops, and an award-winning digital storytelling project. In addition, this project has also produced a new set of artifacts: three prototypes for screen-reader friendly data visualizations. Drawing on this historical and ethnographic work, the PI and co-PI have collaborated with a team of computer scientists to design and test new prototypes that will be implemented in the Vega and Vega-Lite visualization systems. This was the ultimate goal of the project: to influence and build inclusive, accessible data visualizations.
